(Photo: Paul Sancya, Associated Press) 26 CONNECT 5 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
June 2 will be the 7-year anniversary of the infamous Armando Galarraga near-perfect game. 
Though we'll always remember the controversy surrounding that night at Comerica Park – when umpire Jim Joyce incorrectly ruled the final batter safe at first base, preventing Galarraga from recording the first perfect game in Detroit Tigers history – we'll also remember the sportsmanship exuded by both men in how they handled such a difficult situation. 
Joyce, 61, joined three other umpires in retiring from Major League Baseball before the 2017 season. 
Joyce had been an umpire since 1987, working American League games until 2000, when he expanded to the National League. But his name became infamous in the state of Michigan, on June 2, 2010, when he served as first-base umpire during Galarraga's start against the Cleveland Indians. 
With two outs in the ninth inning and a perfect game on the line, Cleveland's Jason Donald hit a ground ball toward the gap between first and second base. First baseman Miguel Cabrera ran toward the ball, grabbed it and threw to Galarraga covering first. 
Donald was out.
